Q: What is consumer surplus? (Example 1)
A: The difference between what consumers are willing to pay and what they actually pay.

Q: What is producer surplus? (Example 2)
A: The difference between what producers are paid and their costs of production.

Q: What is deadweight loss? (Example 3)
A: The loss of total surplus that occurs when a market is not in equilibrium.

Q: What is elasticity? (Example 4)
A: A measure of how much quantity demanded or supplied responds to changes in price.

Q: What is marginal cost? (Example 5)
A: The additional cost of producing one more unit of a good or service.

Q: What is marginal benefit? (Example 6)
A: The additional benefit received from consuming one more unit of a good or service.

Q: What is opportunity cost? (Example 7)
A: The value of the next best alternative that is foregone.

Q: What is a public good? (Example 8)
A: A good that is non-excludable and non-rival in consumption.

Q: What is market failure? (Example 9)
A: When the allocation of goods and services is not efficient.

Q: What is perfect competition? (Example 10)
A: A market structure where many firms sell identical products and no firm has market power.

Q: What is monopoly? (Example 11)
A: A market with a single seller that controls the entire supply of a product.

Q: What is oligopoly? (Example 12)
A: A market structure with a small number of large firms that dominate the market.

Q: What is monopolistic competition? (Example 13)
A: A market structure where many firms sell similar but not identical products.

Q: What is the law of demand? (Example 14)
A: As price decreases, quantity demanded increases, ceteris paribus.

Q: What is the law of supply? (Example 15)
A: As price increases, quantity supplied increases, ceteris paribus.

Q: What is GDP? (Example 16)
A: Gross Domestic Product; the total value of goods and services produced in a country in a given period.

Q: What is inflation? (Example 17)
A: A general increase in prices and fall in the purchasing value of money.

Q: What is unemployment? (Example 18)
A: The condition of someone able to work, looking for work, but unable to find a job.

Q: What is fiscal policy? (Example 19)
A: Government policy regarding taxation and spending.

Q: What is monetary policy? (Example 20)
A: Policy enacted by a central bank to control the money supply and interest rates.

Q: What is comparative advantage? (Example 21)
A: The ability to produce a good at a lower opportunity cost than another producer.

Q: What is absolute advantage? (Example 22)
A: The ability to produce more of a good with the same resources than another producer.

Q: What is a tariff? (Example 23)
A: A tax on imported goods.

Q: What is a quota? (Example 24)
A: A limit on the quantity of a good that can be imported.

Q: What is aggregate demand? (Example 25)
A: The total demand for goods and services in an economy.

Q: What is aggregate supply? (Example 26)
A: The total supply of goods and services that firms are willing and able to produce.

Q: What is stagflation? (Example 27)
A: A combination of stagnant economic growth and inflation.

Q: What is the Phillips curve? (Example 28)
A: A graphical representation of the inverse relationship between inflation and unemployment.

Q: What is the Laffer curve? (Example 29)
A: A curve that shows the relationship between tax rates and tax revenue.

Q: What is the business cycle? (Example 30)
A: The natural rise and fall of economic growth over time.

Q: What is a recession? (Example 31)
A: A period of economic decline typically defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth.

Q: What is a budget deficit? (Example 32)
A: When government spending exceeds revenue.

Q: What is a budget surplus? (Example 33)
A: When government revenue exceeds spending.

Q: What is crowding out? (Example 34)
A: When increased government spending reduces private sector investment.

Q: What is a price ceiling? (Example 35)
A: A legal maximum on the price at which a good can be sold.

Q: What is a price floor? (Example 36)
A: A legal minimum on the price at which a good can be sold.

Q: What is utility? (Example 37)
A: The satisfaction or pleasure derived from consuming a good or service.

Q: What is marginal utility? (Example 38)
A: The additional satisfaction from consuming one more unit.

Q: What is total utility? (Example 39)
A: The total satisfaction received from consuming a given total quantity of a good or service.

Q: What is diminishing marginal utility? (Example 40)
A: The principle that as a person increases consumption, the marginal utility declines.

Q: What is the law of diminishing returns? (Example 41)
A: The principle that adding more of one input will eventually yield lower per-unit returns.

Q: What is the production possibilities frontier? (Example 42)
A: A curve showing all maximum output possibilities for two goods.

Q: What is a normal good? (Example 43)
A: A good for which demand increases as income rises.

Q: What is an inferior good? (Example 44)
A: A good for which demand decreases as income rises.

Q: What is a complementary good? (Example 45)
A: A good that is consumed with another good.

Q: What is a substitute good? (Example 46)
A: A good that can replace another in consumption.

Q: What is the equilibrium price? (Example 47)
A: The price at which quantity demanded equals quantity supplied.

Q: What is market equilibrium? (Example 48)
A: The point where supply equals demand.

Q: What is price discrimination? (Example 49)
A: Charging different prices to different consumers for the same good.

Q: What is the tragedy of the commons? (Example 50)
A: Overuse of a shared resource due to individual incentives.

Q: What is total utility? (Example 804)
A: The total satisfaction received from consuming a given total quantity of a good or service.

Q: What is diminishing marginal utility? (Example 805)
A: The principle that as a person increases consumption, the marginal utility declines.

Q: What is the law of diminishing returns? (Example 806)
A: The principle that adding more of one input will eventually yield lower per-unit returns.

Q: What is the production possibilities frontier? (Example 807)
A: A curve showing all maximum output possibilities for two goods.

Q: What is a normal good? (Example 808)
A: A good for which demand increases as income rises.

Q: What is an inferior good? (Example 809)
A: A good for which demand decreases as income rises.

Q: What is a complementary good? (Example 810)
A: A good that is consumed with another good.

Q: What is a substitute good? (Example 811)
A: A good that can replace another in consumption.

Q: What is the equilibrium price? (Example 812)
A: The price at which quantity demanded equals quantity supplied.

Q: What is market equilibrium? (Example 813)
A: The point where supply equals demand.

Q: What is price discrimination? (Example 814)
A: Charging different prices to different consumers for the same good.

Q: What is the tragedy of the commons? (Example 815)
A: Overuse of a shared resource due to individual incentives.

Q: What is externality? (Example 816)
A: A cost or benefit that affects a third party not directly involved in a transaction.

Q: What is consumer surplus? (Example 817)
A: The difference between what consumers are willing to pay and what they actually pay.

Q: What is producer surplus? (Example 818)
A: The difference between what producers are paid and their costs of production.

Q: What is deadweight loss? (Example 819)
A: The loss of total surplus that occurs when a market is not in equilibrium.

Q: What is elasticity? (Example 820)
A: A measure of how much quantity demanded or supplied responds to changes in price.

Q: What is marginal cost? (Example 821)
A: The additional cost of producing one more unit of a good or service.

Q: What is marginal benefit? (Example 822)
A: The additional benefit received from consuming one more unit of a good or service.

Q: What is opportunity cost? (Example 823)
A: The value of the next best alternative that is foregone.

Q: What is a public good? (Example 824)
A: A good that is non-excludable and non-rival in consumption.

Q: What is market failure? (Example 825)
A: When the allocation of goods and services is not efficient.

Q: What is perfect competition? (Example 826)
A: A market structure where many firms sell identical products and no firm has market power.

Q: What is monopoly? (Example 827)
A: A market with a single seller that controls the entire supply of a product.

Q: What is oligopoly? (Example 828)
A: A market structure with a small number of large firms that dominate the market.

Q: What is monopolistic competition? (Example 829)
A: A market structure where many firms sell similar but not identical products.

Q: What is the law of demand? (Example 830)
A: As price decreases, quantity demanded increases, ceteris paribus.

Q: What is the law of supply? (Example 831)
A: As price increases, quantity supplied increases, ceteris paribus.

Q: What is GDP? (Example 832)
A: Gross Domestic Product; the total value of goods and services produced in a country in a given period.

Q: What is inflation? (Example 833)
A: A general increase in prices and fall in the purchasing value of money.

Q: What is unemployment? (Example 834)
A: The condition of someone able to work, looking for work, but unable to find a job.

Q: What is fiscal policy? (Example 835)
A: Government policy regarding taxation and spending.

Q: What is monetary policy? (Example 836)
A: Policy enacted by a central bank to control the money supply and interest rates.

Q: What is comparative advantage? (Example 837)
A: The ability to produce a good at a lower opportunity cost than another producer.

Q: What is absolute advantage? (Example 838)
A: The ability to produce more of a good with the same resources than another producer.

Q: What is a tariff? (Example 839)
A: A tax on imported goods.

Q: What is a quota? (Example 840)
A: A limit on the quantity of a good that can be imported.

Q: What is aggregate demand? (Example 841)
A: The total demand for goods and services in an economy.

Q: What is aggregate supply? (Example 842)
A: The total supply of goods and services that firms are willing and able to produce.

Q: What is stagflation? (Example 843)
A: A combination of stagnant economic growth and inflation.

Q: What is the Phillips curve? (Example 844)
A: A graphical representation of the inverse relationship between inflation and unemployment.

Q: What is the Laffer curve? (Example 845)
A: A curve that shows the relationship between tax rates and tax revenue.

Q: What is the business cycle? (Example 846)
A: The natural rise and fall of economic growth over time.

Q: What is a recession? (Example 847)
A: A period of economic decline typically defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth.

Q: What is a budget deficit? (Example 848)
A: When government spending exceeds revenue.

Q: What is a budget surplus? (Example 849)
A: When government revenue exceeds spending.

Q: What is crowding out? (Example 850)
A: When increased government spending reduces private sector investment.
